results.headline: Tracking an Assassin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chapter 27

results.summary_short: Any film that dares attempt a nonjudgmental portrait of John Lennon’s assassin would most likely be accused of tastelessness, but in the case of “Chapter 27” the charges are justified.

results.headline: My Brother, My Rival: Those Ties That Bind and Chafe
results.display_title: My Brother is an Only Child

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Brother is an Only Child

results.summary_short: “My Brother Is an Only Child” is a lively minor addendum to the grand tradition of Italian fraternal cinema.

results.headline: Celebrating Masculine Immaturity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Backseat

results.summary_short: The flailing, protagonists of “Backseat,” while not exactly 40-year-old virgins, can have avoided that fate only by the tender mercies of women with low expectations.

results.headline: With Assist From Greed, Money Makes the Man

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 21

results.summary_short: Greed is good and comes without a hint of conscience in “21,” a feature-length bore about some smarty-pants who take Vegas for a ride.

results.headline: Back From Iraq, on a Road Going Nowhere

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stop-Loss

results.summary_short: In some ways, there is a grim, accidental timeliness in the release of “Stop-Loss,” which focuses on the ordeal of American soldiers in and out of combat.

results.headline: Birth of Los Angeles Art, Assisted by Hip Midwives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cool School

results.summary_short: “The Cool School,” a breezy, lively documentary about a thin slice of the Los Angeles fine art scene in the 1950s, is easy on the eyes, and the ears too.

results.headline: A Widow Roaming the Chechen Front, With Curiosity and History in Tow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alexandra

results.summary_short: Alexander Sokurov’s “Alexandra” feels like a communiqué from another time, another place, anywhere but here.

results.headline: Half-Brothers Mired in Full-Blown Hate

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shotgun Stories

results.summary_short: “Shotgun Stories” defines the classic western phrase “doing what a man’s got to do” as both a moral imperative and a biological compulsion.

results.headline: Serving a Buffet of Morality and Humor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry’s Meet the Browns

results.summary_short: Tyler Perry's work may be rooted in the experience of a particular group, but there is nothing exclusive about it.

results.headline: A Haunting Intruder From the Darkroom

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shutter

results.summary_short: Fans of J-horror (for Japan, where the genre was born; its conventions have since spread to South Korea and Thailand) will find “Shutter” familiar; others may just doze.

results.headline: Allegations Against a Government
results.display_title: Poisoned by Polonium: The Litvinenko File

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poisoned by Polonium: The Litvinenko File

results.summary_short: “Poisoned by Polonium” is an extraordinary testament to a man whose incendiary allegations against his government might have had fatal consequences.

results.headline: Sex, Blood and Exotica in an Anti-Thriller Thriller

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boarding Gate

results.summary_short: “Boarding Gate” plays with various genre codes and conventions very differently than most run-of-the-mill modern thrillers.

results.headline: Escaping a Meek Old Age With an Erotic New Job

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Irina Palm

results.summary_short: “Irina Palm” may be the work of a German-born Belgian director, but it belongs to a sturdy and very British genre: the naughty-granny comedy.

results.headline: Working-Class Swagger

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hammer

results.summary_short: “The Hammer,” although rambling and disorganized, also has dry wit and hits some surprising emotional notes.

results.headline: Poker Faces

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grand

results.summary_short: In “The Grand,” the actors certainly look as if they’re having a good time, and if you’re in the right mood, you might too.

results.headline: Break Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Planet B-Boy

results.summary_short: From moment to moment, “Planet B-Boy” is fun, sometimes thrilling and packed with illuminating details and striking personalities.

results.headline: Protector With Big Shtick for 3 High School Nerds

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drillbit Taylor

results.summary_short: “You get what you pay for,” the tag line on the advertisement for “Drillbit Taylor” says. I saw it free, and I still feel cheated.

results.headline: Mother and Son, Divided by Border, United by Phone

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tenichibo to Iganosuke

results.summary_short: Directed, with visible earnestness, by Patricia Riggen, “Under the Same Moon” blunts the hard edges of immigration with a thick coating of preciousness.

results.headline: Parisians Singing From Bed to Bed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Songs

results.summary_short: The melodies in “Love Songs” are charming and so, for the most part, is the movie, even if it doesn’t entirely work.

results.headline: On Other Side of the World, Life Is Still Upside Down

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ling Yi Ban

results.summary_short: Ying Liang’s slyly subversive second feature takes awhile to coalesce, but once it does, it becomes an intriguing exercise in juxtaposition.
